title: Costa Rica: Citi Opens Nominations for Its Sixth Annual Microentrepreneurship Award
summary: San José, Costa Rica - Citi, the Citi Foundation and the ADRI Association announced the opening of nominations for the sixth annual Citi Microentrepreneurship Awards in Costa Rica.
tag-1: Costa Rica: Citi Opens Nominations for Its Sixth Annual Microentrepreneurship Award
tag-3: San José, Costa Rica – Citi, the Citi Foundation and the ADRI Association announced the opening of nominations for the sixth annual Citi Microentrepreneurship Awards in Costa Rica.
tag-4: Economics, Industry and Trade Minister Mayi Antillón and representatives of microcredit and business development service providers will participate in the launch event for the award, which aims to recognize the important role of microenterprise in the growth of the Costa Rican economy. Its goal is to stimulate and promote microfinance as a tool for development and poverty reduction and to present the experiences of successful microenterprises as models for others to emulate.
tag-5: "ADRI has been working with the Citi Foundation to offer this award since 2007. Whenever we see a microentrepreneur succeed, we become even more convinced of the support this project provides for this sector and the country. To date, approximately 100 microenterprises around the country have participated in the contest each year. More than 25 have received a total of $100,000 in awards. The winners have used the funds to pay off loans, invest in business tools and improve their homes and family living conditions," explained Juan Pablo Montoya, ADRI's General Manager.
tag-6: There have been many examples. In 2011, an outstanding case was Mrs. Rosario Ramírez Brenes, who won the award for Female Microentrepreneur for her costume jewelry company Bisutería en Vidrio. The award helped her grow her business in terms of both marketing and production, and today she exports her products. In coming weeks, she will travel to Korea to represent the Costa Rican handcraft industry at an event there.
tag-7: In 2011, the contest also introduced a "Grand Prize Winner," selected by a judges' committee from the Inter-American Development Bank. Kevin Robles of Artesanías Diprok won this honor, to great applause from the audience. In a video filmed in 2011, Kevin told how doctors predicted he had little chance for success in life due to a series of physical handicaps, but he proved them wrong by starting a successful business with the help of his family.
tag-8: "Citi pleased to offer the VI Micro-Entrepreneurship Awards as part of our 200th anniversary celebrations," remarked Marcelo Gorrini, Citi Costa Rica CCO. "We are a bank that works continuously to support the country's social and economic development and accompany important projects. Our presence in Costa Rica goes back more than 40 years, and we haven't once stopped working for the community. This fills us with pride, and this initiative is the symbol of our commitment to corporate social responsibility."
tag-10: Microentrepreneurs who would like to be considered for the award must be nominated by an association, foundation, business chamber, solidarity association, savings and loan cooperative or other group that supports microenterprise. Nominations will also be accepted from state-owned or private commercial banks with microfinance programs. Only these institutions may nominate micro-entrepreneurs who meet the eligibility requirements.
tag-11: Participation is free for all Costa Rican microenterprises and those residing in this country. Candidates must have a maximum of five employees and annual sales that do not exceed $150,000 and meet other prerequisites detailed in the "Award Rules."
tag-12: This year's award categories are: Trade, Industry, Services, Female Entrepreneur, Most Environmentally Friendly Enterprise and Best Rural Group that Manages Rural Credit. The MICROENTREPRENEUR OF THE YEAR will be selected from among the winners of these categories.
tag-13: Nominations must be received at the ADRI Association Offices in Centro Comercial Plaza Mayor, Rohrmoser, 225 metros sur, across from the ICE station, to the attention of Mr. Juan Pablo Montoya, by 4 p.m. Friday, September 14, 2012.
tag-15: To maintain the award's high standards, a specialized judges' committee will select the winners. The committee is composed of a representative of the Ministry of Economics and Trade; Armando González, President of AM/PM Investments; Roinel Vargas, Executive Director of the Costa Rican Microcredit Network; Eduardo Sibaia, former Economics Minister and current Director General of CENAT; Mauricio Alvarado, Risk Director, Citi; Antonio Paulo Conde, Consumer Products Director, Citi; and Claudia Zambrano, Finance Director, Citi.
tag-16: For more information about the award, please visit www.adricr.com or www.adri.co.cr.
tag-17: Citi Foundation The Citi Foundation is committed to the economic empowerment and financial inclusion of individuals and families, particularly those in need, in the communities where we work so that they can improve their standard of living. Globally, the Citi Foundation targets its strategic giving to priority focus areas: Microfinance, Enterprise Development, Youth Education and Livelihoods, and Financial Capability and Asset Building. The Citi Foundation works with its partners in Microfinance and Enterprise Development to support environmental programs and innovations. Additional information can be found at www.citifoundation.com.
